sub_title: Lead Project Service & Control at Philips
summary:
I am an energetic professional with experience in managing multi-cultural teams. I thrive in complex work environment that offer many challenges.  Improving processes and tooling is close to my heart. I bring people together and rally them around a common cause. Overcoming difficulties, managing the change at people, get what customers need and tying up the loose ends gives me energy.

How I contribute

By combining an inquisitive mind with active listening:
Improvements to processes and tooling don’t come easy. I strongly believe that the best results are achieved by building strong relations between people and engaging in active listening to get to the bottom of things. I combine this attitude with an open mind seeking alternatives and solid solutions.

By having a solution oriented focus:
It is all about moving in the right direction in our ever changing businesses. Today’s solutions can be tomorrow’s burdens. In getting to where we need to be I employ a strong motivation and persistence as change can be hard to achieve. I bring the energy that helps inspire the spark of change.

By complementing structured communication with active progress tracking:
Knowing where you are relative to where you need to be is the key to success. I like to take the Lead in the change as I work from a clear focus. The communication I send regarding progress provides required clarity, focus and a sense of urgency.


Contact me if you see an opportunity for me to help you solve your problems. You can reach me at the following location:

- +31(0)6 21887968

projects.title: Clarity PMSG deployment
projects.description:
Project description: 
Clarity PMSG will replace the current Clarity application for IT with the Clarity implementation as selected in the Philips Integrated Landscape (PIL) program. I serve as the Product Owner to represent the business and to ensure correct communications between the Business and the Agile Project team. As Such I work together with the Program Manager to identify and describe the Business Processes.

Business process models of all major processes touching Clarity IT
Fit Gap analysis Clarity IT vs Clarity PMSG
Scoping of the replacement project
Lean Project Charter Clarity PMSG
Deployment of Clarity PMSG, SAP PS and all related processes

projects.title: CF_Gemini Finance: Samba
projects.description:
Project description: 
The Gemini SAMBA project served a number of purposes. It delivered (i) a complete upgrade of the outdated SAMBA technical environment, (ii) it delivered a split of that technical environment to serve the two companies emerging from the Gemini split of Philips and (iii) it deployed the SAMBA application in the newly formed Philips Lighting company.

Main Deliverables: 
Upgrade the current SAMBA environment for the Application and Database server parts
Ensure proper operations for the upgraded application environments
Documentation of the new SAMBA environment
Global deployment of the new client side software to global customer community
Design and create user training materials
Train new user communities on the SAMBA application
Global deployment of the new middleware software to the globa user community
Definition of new SAMBA instances for the new Philips Lighting user communities
Master data design, creation and deployment for the new Philips Lighting communities
Alignment of the new master data design to connect to the new SAP environment of Philips Lighting
Arrange first, second and third line support for the new SAMBA environments
Arrange outsoursing of transactional work for the new Philips Lighting organization to InfoSys

My role(s): 
Functional Lead, Project Manager

My responsibilities: 
I first served as a Functional Lead to guide the project through its upgrade phase. In that capacity I ensured full User Acceptence testing accross the globe and help pass the first Gemini Project Stage gate. I then served as the Project Manager in the deployment phase of the project, delivering the upgraded application to the original and new business audiences. This required designing, building and deploying of all master data for the new SAMBA application and deploying the new application to the new user communities.

projects.title: Improvement OOM
projects.description:
Project description: 
The project aimed to improve the financial operations of the Organizational Reporting Unit that was created earlier in the year. It focused on solving compliance issues and strengthening Month End Closure (MEC) processing. It needed to decrease the confusion between organizations, improve the quality of the financial outcomes and expedite financial processing

Main Deliverables: 
Outline, define and improve the Purchase Order (PO) creation process in the ORU
Implement and extend the Accrual process in IT and the other Global Service Units
Introduce MEC tracking functionality in Accounting Operations
Introduce central Inter COmpany Accounting (ICA) charging in the ORU
Define and align SAP master data management in conjunction with related system master data management
Enhance SAP cycling
Introduce central Hedging forcasting

My role(s): 
Project Manager, Functional Lead

My responsibilities: 
I was responsible for (i) PO process improvements in relation to PO compliance, (ii) improving the internal charging within the ORU, (iii) implementation of centralized SAMBA charging for the ORU and (iv) to implement a centralized Cost Center related master data management approach accross six application to ensure alignment between these systems.

projects.title: ORU Merge
projects.description:
Project description: 
Project was defined to financially merge five Organizational Reporting Units (ORUs) to form the new Global Services Units organization. This meant (i) the centralization of all GSU related cost into a single Organizational Reporting Unit (ORUs) and (ii) to redirect all finance processing from the original ORUs to the target ORUs, (iii) update all affected systems and applications and (iv) train all people involved in the transfer.

Main Deliverables: 
ORU merger cookbook
ORU Merger approach and process
Staff transfers from old ORU to new ORU
Transfer of Assets and Balances of the original ORUs to the new ORUs
Transferral of active Purchase Orders (POs) from the original ORUs to the new ORUs
Creation of required master data for target applications and systems
Configured applications (SAP, Clarity, SAMBA)
Training of all involved staffing
Creation of consolidated financial reporting over the newly created ORU

My role(s): 
Subject Matter Expert

My responsibilities: 
I was responsible for the creation of new master data for the SAP, SAMBA and Clarity applications. This required analysis, definition and creation of the new master data based on the master data in the original ORUs. It also required testing and alignment on the financial processes that depended on this new master data in the resulting ORU. Next to that I was responsible for the transfer of active Purchase Orders from the original ORUs into the target ORU. The final assignment I had was to co-work on the ORU merger Cookbook for the master data and PO Transfer parts.

projects.title: Asset Direct Charging
projects.description:
Project description: 
The project aimed to transform the existing Asset Direct Charging application from an Expense-basis to a Depreciation-basis. This required the implementation of a new way of charge calculations to prepare for Inter Company Accounting charging for the Sectors. A complete new charging approach had to be aligned with the financial booking changes in SAP between the IT GSU and its Sector based customers.

Main Deliverables: 
Define the new Asset Depreciation approach for Laptops, Desktops, Workstations and Tablets
Define and design the new ADC database to support Depreciation based ICA charging
Build the new ADC database
Roll out the new ADC database within the IT Operations Office

My role(s): 
Project Manager, Subject Matter Expert

My responsibilities: 
It was my responsibility to redesign the existing ADC application to support the new Depreciation-based ICA charging and the alignment of that new application to the current charging practice. Next to that I had the responsibility to build the application and to deploy it within the Operations Office.

Create a reporting capability that allows on consisten cross service reporting for all IT Infrastructure services, providing transparency in service consumption and service costs. This Financial reporting initiative needed to clarify the relation between the various types of service provided, the costs related to these services and the level to which these cost could be influenced by changes in service consumption.

Define and agree on QxP governance model
Define and agree on a Quantity vs Price reporting approach

Project Manager

I defined the framework and implemented from scratch a solution to support it. This solution delivered full insight into costs and consumption values of the main cost drivers for the services delivered by IT Infrastructure.

projects.title: FCR Invoice automation
projects.description:
Project description: 
In an effort to improve financial reporting Philips decided to implement functional cost reporting and decided to automate the automatic posing of invoices to support that. The project aimed to employ the defined SAP INPA automated posting solution to the maximum level possible. This meant global configuration of the SAP INPA tables for all Philips' Organizational Reporting Units (ORUs). All these ORUs (750) were set up to automatically post the internal charges coming from the Global Service Units of Philips.

Main Deliverables: 
Definition of the analysis and configuration definition approach
Analyze curent Inter Company Accounting (ICA) charges
Identify all required ORU to ORU pairs and their ICA charging relation per GSU
Create tooling to generate INPA configuration entries
Generate INPA Configuration table entries per ORU to ORU combination
Load and validate INPA table entries

My role(s): 
Subject Matter Expert

My responsibilities: 
For the IT function I was responsible to analyze and report on all SAP to SAP relations between the two IT Global Service Units and the four Sectors of Philips. I was also responsible for the required communication to the businesses in the Sectors with regards to the automation of these SAP to SAP relations. Next to that I was responsible for the generation of all configuration settings that would allow for automated postings from the GSUs to the Sectors.

OPIO Wrapup

Collected remaining pockets IT Cost for financial assets and services from the Sectors and start negotiations for a controlled move to the IT Infrastructure department. Incorporate these collected Assets, Services and People from the Sector organizations to the IT Infrastructure organization. Ensure proper definition of new services, transfer of financial responsibilities and align staffing with the new IT Infrastructure setup. Identify pockets of IT Assets and Services in the Sectors
Define reporting on pocket status and activities
Transfer pockets into IT Infrastructure, sever old connections
Transfer staff from the Sectors into IT Infrastructure
Train transferred staff on IT Infrastructure procedures and processes
Financial transfer of staff, assets and processing in alignment with the SAP ledger for IT Infrastructure
Define scoping definitions to describe IT for IT Infrastructure and Sector IT

Project Manager

I was responsible for setting up the processes and communications. After that I led a team of SAP analysts that collected data required for the transfer. During that time I was also responsible form cross departmental communications and the reporting to upper management on progress.

projects.title: Sector to IT GSU reconciliation
projects.description:
Project description: 
The project was aimed at clarifying the relation between IT Infrastructure and IT Applications ICA charging and postings in the Sector General Ledger. It provided insight into main deviations between the the IT Organizations and the Sectors. Insights were delivered on Sector, country, Organizational Reporting Unit (ORU) level. Reconciliation results were used to trigger cleanup and correction activities in the SAP Ledgers of the involved organizations. A standard way of reconciliation reporting was defined and agreed upon.

Main Deliverables: 
Define and agree on a reconciliation reporting approach
Create reconciliation reporting tooling
Define reconciliation process and define correction approaches
Define a standard list of common deviation causes and the corrective approach for each
Prepare for running the the reconciliation process on a regular monthly basis in the standing organization
Transfer the reconciliation process to the finance organization

My role(s): 
Project Manager

My responsibilities: 
As a financial project manager I was responsible to lead a team of SAP analysts in an effort to improve invoice reconciliation between all internal departments of Philips. I led the taskforce that implemented improvement actions related to our analysis. I was also responsible for the improvement of interdepartmental communication on invoice reconciliation between the two IT Global Service Units and the four Sectors of Philips.

projects.title: Connect Vault Service Creation
projects.description:
Project description: 
The project was aimed at creating a service out of a technically defined solution for the secure storage and exchange of sensitive files. It had to make sure all service elements were created and properly deployed into the managed operations organization. To do so it had to define a standardized way in which such transfers were supposed to take place. It put the Handover document approach into the standard ITIL service creation process for IT Infrastructure.

Main Deliverables: 
Identify all required service elements needed for the execution of proper managed opertions of services
Definition and description of all required service elements
Definition of handover procedures between service creation projects and managed operations organizations
Definition and description of a Service Handover document
Creation of all applicable service creation elements for the Connect Vault service
Transfer of the Connect Vault service into managed operations through service handover

My role(s): 
Project Manager, Subject Matter Expert

My responsibilities: 
I managed the project from start to finish in order to create the new Connect Vault service within managed operations. I worked together with the ITIL process group to define and describe the Service Handover document. After that I worked with the Finance team to define the required financial documentation, with the managed operations team to define the operational documentation required to transfer the service into production. Untimately I worked with the Service Delivery organization to put the Connect Vault Service into production.

Create a Process Design for Information Management (IM) and set up IM by creating the necessary organization, processes and tooling to support it. Implement these processes in the business by aligning them with the Service Lines and the appointment, mandation and training of Data Stewards. Creation of an Information Backbone and the population of this IB with master data sets to be maintained by the Data Stewards.

Main Deliverables: 
Process design for Information Management
Tooling for Information Management (Information Backbone, IB)
Alignment with the Service Line Managers on IM approach and execution
Identification, definition and description of master data sets in scope
Identification and activation of Data Stewards in the business
Population of IB with current master data sets
Cleanup of current master data sets in IB

Subject Matter Expert (SME)

As a SME I had three main tasks. First I was responsible for the setup of processes designs for IM. Secondly I co-desinged with the TechLead on the setup of infrastructure for the Information Backbone of IT Infra. projects.title: Connect Mobile Service Creation
projects.description:
Project description: 
The project aimed to standardize the mobile devices provided per Philips region as part of the Connect Mobile service. It had the purpose to reduced the number of the make and model combinations. This to get grip on cost, technical capabilities, security and functionality provided by the mobiles deployed. Regional differences in mobile availability, service provider as well as cultural differences had to be balanced against cost and manageability.

Main Deliverables: 
List of standard make and model mobiles provisioned
Service description for mobile provisioning
Negotiated contracts with service provider in all Philips regions
Alignment (where) possible between approaches applied in various Philips regions
Costing model for each Philips region
Published service description and service requesting tooling

My role(s): 
Project Manager

My responsibilities: 
Manage the project through running separate but aligned sub-projects in each region. I aligned the people in each region with the SME identified for that region. I made sure that each relatively independent region coordinated their efforts with each other and with other regions. Next to that I worked with the teams to get make and model lists defined and agreed.

Assignment: 
The task was to get a bug-ridden and non-performing Lotus Notes planning and scheduling application to perform well and consistently. 

Responsibilities: 
I was tasked within B&G to rework a home-grown CRM system to get it to work properly. It required me to run a project to enable the proper planning, control, execution and closure of all required work.

Achievements: 
I managed to bug fix their non-performing server by correcting the setup of the planning and scheduling software running on it. In that application I also eliminated all productivity degrading software bugs, enhancing its usability considerably. 

Main lessons learnt: 
Key learning points: (i) developed the necessary skills that allowed me to listen carefully to customers and technicians to deduce causes of errors and (ii) how to find, describe, analyze and correct problems in a structured and efficient manner.
profile_positions.title: Software Lead

profile_positions.description:
Employed by the Consortium Informatica Diensten (CID, Zaandam, The Netherlands) I was contracted by IBM.

Assignment: 
An assignment was given to create a Sales Offering information application after that various other applications within IBMs HR environment. 

Responsibilities: 
I worked as the software architect on all of these application creation projects. For most I projects I was assigned to co-develop the software and for some I also executed the project management.

Achievements: 
Two examples of software I built were the high-secure Vacation Planner and the second version of the Sales Offering converter. 

Main lessons learnt: 
Key learnings were: (i) insight into impact privacy requirements and other legal on projects, (ii) importance of a design for performance from the start, (iii) testing is a process that needs a very structured approach and (iv) managing IT projects using PRINCE2 project management
profile_positions.title: Software Architect

profile_positions.description:
Employed by the Consortium Informatica Diensten (CID, Zaandam, The Netherlands) I was contracted by IBM.

Assignment: 
Create software that helped IBM to transform the IT basis for its Sales Offering process.

Responsibilities: 
I was asked to do code development, testing and deployment for a large number of projects within IBM. For some of the projects I had to perform the project manager role.

Achievements: 
Some examples applications were a MVS mainframe based telecom exchange program and software for mainframe to Louts Notes conversions. I managed to become IBM certified at the highest level for the Lotus Notes and Domino platform.

Main lessons learnt: 
Key learnings achieved: (i) working with complexities of large scale migrations and (ii) understanding the need for a common vocabulary in communication with the customers
profile_positions.title: Software Developer

profile_positions.description:
Assignment: 
The main goal was to ensure that the VM mainframe environment became a state-of-the-art environment, keeping shop-open at all times. 

Responsibilities: 
I had the technical end-responsibility over the VM part of a large mainframe shop. It required me to guarantee system safety and health to end-users and to keep services and software up to date. 

Achievements: 
I defined, designed and implemented a growth-based system security system. Next to that I assured the upgrading of the very old back-level mainframe VM system to a state-of-the-art OS level.

Main lessons learnt: 
Key learning points were: (i) using roadmaps and to plan ahead and (ii) carrying the end-responsibility for a technical infrastructure.
profile_positions.title: Systems Programmer

profile_positions.description:
Assignment: 
The goal was to keep a VM mainframe environment available every day and to keep it aligned with customer requirements. 

Responsibilities: 
I had the responsibility for the maintenance of the system software running in the VM mainframe shop. Next to that I was acting as a participant in customer merger projects.

Achievements: 
Together with customers I achieved the consolidation of mainframe systems into our own environment. I also arranged the cleanup of years of backlog system maintenance to the mainframe OS. 

Main lessons learnt: 
My key learning points were: (i) balancing specific user requests against needs of community, (ii) dealing with the pressure of ensuring that services are always available and (iii) working with Change Management and System Security.
profile_positions.title: Systems Controller

volunteer_experiences.description:
Through my neighbor I was introduced to Radio Contact, an in-house radio station at Vita Nova, a rest-home in my home town. I was trained as a studio technician to team up with a presenter to create engaging radio shows. 

Besides being active as  studio technician I also participated in various activities bring activities and joy in the rest-house. This involved the yearly Sinterklaas and Christmas celebrations and various activities organized throughout the year.

I was member of the board of the Zuid West subdivision of the Dutch table tennis union (Nederlandse Tafel Tennis Bond, NTTB). In my role as board member Technical Affairs engaged in the day-to-day affairs of the subdivision board. This involved participating in finance, competition, communication and technical management. As such I was Chairman of the Technical Affairs committee. 

This committee had the responsibility to organize talent recognition, organizing sub-division level training for talented players and to liaise between all clubs (94 at that time) belonging to the subdivision. During my period I managed to reorganize the poor loss-making financial situation towards break-even.  I solved various long running conflicts negatively affecting the committee by reorganizing the committees staffing.

In parallel with my Technical Affairs activities at the NTTB subdivision I was doing the same work at my own club OTTC. This meant keeping the alignment between OTTC and the NTTB subdivision in place on Technical Affairs. Within my own club (OTTC) I participated in the club's board, handling Technical affairs as my main attention but was also involved in communication, finance, automation and organizing activities throughout the year.

My main responsibility was to organize all topics revolving around Technical Affairs. This meant dividing players into teams, registration of teams in the subdivision competitions, talent recognition for the young, organizing training for all club members and financial management of the Technical Affairs section of the club.

At the retirement of the previous club chairman I took over after being recommended by the remaining board members. I chaired the board of my club for 8 years, driving the club's activities, supporting and motivating its board members and acting as a clubs confidant, resolving conflicts between club members. 

I had special attention for the clubs financials due to my experience in previous positions in the NTTB subdivision and my position prior to my Presidency. I combined this with my knowledge of IT, driving the efficiency and effectiveness of the clubs automation various topics.

I spend many a week being present at my club on 4-6 days of the week. It was a very gratifying period in my life as I had to combine that with my children growing up and achieving a MBA master degree. I could only achieve this due to the close knit of people around me at home and at my club.

I was asked to take over the chairman position of the Parent Board, at the primary school my daughters attended, after being recommended by the leaving chairman. As parent board we worked with the school director and the teacher core and the childrens parents to achieve the best education we could provide for our children. 

This involved matters of finance, conflict resolution, improvement in ground keeping around the school and most importantly trying to keep the school alive. The primary school was located in an area with multiple other primary schools during a time of demographic changes.

The NTTB at that time worked with a vendor to automate its core registration system but ran into difficulties with the delivered functionalities, the associated cost, maintainability of the solution and the timing of the delivery. I was asked to participate in a three person audit team to audit the whole project on these points and come with recommendations for next steps the NTTB could take. 

We studied available documentation to understand how the current position was achieved as well as the alignment of that position to the original intent. Interviews with the main stakeholders, on the NTTB and the vendor side, were held to clarify each stakeholder's intent, actions and position.

We created an audit report that detailed on process related issues and suggested improvements to the NTTB board that related to planning, guidance, reporting and the development process used. Next to that we suggested the NTTB board improvements for the product itself as well as for the way it dealt with the intellectual property of the solution defined.

Part of my MBA tuition at Tias Nimbas business school was to participate in a personal development training that took me to The Gambia. Students were required to execute a local development project.  Cattle is running loose in the whole of The Gambia but the soil is fertile. Local villages cannot grow vegetables for themselves as those will be eaten by their cattle before these vegetables can be harvested. As a result their diet does not contain enough vegetables as purchasing these on the local markets is too expensive. 

A zero technology footprint concept was defined in close cooperation with representatives of the local village of Jakaba. Fencing a plot of land fitted with sufficient wells would solve the loose cattle problem. Agricultural training to villagers taught them to effectively and efficiently grow their vegetables on their properties. Good quality seeds in combination with agricultural knowledge and fenced-in land delivered the solution these villagers required. 

Since that time I continued the initiative by raising the required funds for an additional 6 villages in the Kuntaur area. I still worked with the same local Dutch woman who was working with the villages who wanted to participate. We met with representatives, discussed their needs, assessed their willingness to invest as well (one-third of total budget to be furnished by the villagers) and defined the required budget. I then worked in The Netherlands to raised the required funds and, once done, transferred the money to my local Dutch contact. My next visit to The Gambia would restart the cycle.

The vegetable gardens impact people's lives in two distinct ways. First the local diets improved through the increased level of vegetable consumption. At the same time the surplus of vegetables grown was sold off on the local markets. The funds so generated were used to send village children to school who would otherwise have been deprived of education.

After stepping down as Chairman of my club I was asked to join the Financial committee in order to retain my knowledge and know-how for the club. In the committee I work on the creation of the annual budget as well as the annual reporting on the club's financial performance. Next to that I am involved in long term financial planning of building maintenance, energy consumption reduction initiatives and fund raising.

The municipality of Oss is very active to get its population to participate more intensively in sports and healthy activities. One of its initiatives was to ask local sports clubs to participate in the Sports Alliance. The aim was to strengthen the local sports clubs by enhancing their activities to get more members, share knowledge and know-how and to work together on joint communication in the area of sports.

I was mandated by my club, OTTC, to participate on their behalf and was elected the first chairman of the Sports Alliance. As chairman I ensured meetings were planned and took place and helped driving the Sports Alliance to define its purpose and its way of working. I liaised with the municipality, the Sports Alliance members as well as the board of my club. In the end the Sports Alliance was discontinued as it showed lack of results in the area of increased sports participation of the people of Oss.

I volunteered to coach, together with one and later three others, a team of youngsters at the hockey club in Oss. My youngest daughter started playing hockey and was added to a hockey team which needed an additional coach. Since then I've worked with the children to enhance their insight in the game and to help motivate and stimulate them. I organize the winter training sessions to engage the children in hockey during the winter competition stop.

I support the Samenloop voor Hoop initiative as an IT Specialist. The Samenloop voor Hoop initiative raises money to support cancer research in the Netherlands. I provide IT support for the Finance team and for the communications team. This results in automated mailing generators and automatically generated financial reporting.
